prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
Aita for giving a woman a taste of her own behavior
I'm sitting at the airport and this older lady sat down right next to me and took her iPad out and starts watching a show quite loud. 

To me this is a foul in public however I just ignored it and put my earbuds in. 

After a while I made a phone call using my earbuds. Literally 30 seconds into my call she interrupts me and asks me to quit being rude and talk quietly so she can hear her show.

I was as polite as I could and said that not only herself but everyone for about 10 feet and I could hear her show word for word and that making a phone call isn't rude but watching a show on your device full volume in a public waiting area is actually very rude and that is why people use headphones. 

She said she has every right to enjoy her show without being interrupted by a rude and selfish phone call or having to use headphones. 

I said she was absolutely right and I am completely wrong, please enjoy your show while we  wait for the plane and I will do  the same.       I then proceeded to take out my iPad and open ice cubes good cop bad cop music video and play it full volume on my device without my earbuds. 

I have never seen someone storm off so mad. 


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. So the question is whether the person who wrote this story is in the wrong. Let me read through the details again.

The scenario is at an airport. An older lady sits next to the author and watches a show on her iPad loudly. The author initially ignores it and uses earbuds. Then when the author makes a phone call, the lady interrupts and tells the author to talk quietly. The author responds by pointing out that the lady is also being loud and that using earbuds would be better. Then the author sarcastically agrees that they're wrong, and then plays a music video full volume on their iPad, causing the lady to storm off.

Hmm. So the key points here are about public etiquette and whether the author's retaliation was justified. Both parties were being disruptive in public. The lady was using her device loudly, and the author was on a phone call. But in public spaces, people do have certain expectations. Usually, phone calls are supposed to be on speakerphone or headphones, and watching videos without headphones is also considered rude. 

The author's response to the lady's complaint was to mock her by doing the same thing. That might be seen as escalating the situation. Even though the lady started it, the author's actions could be seen as retaliatory and equally rude. Public spaces require a level of mutual respect, and while both were in the wrong initially, the author's response might have been an overreaction. 

The lady had the right to ask for quiet, and the author had the right to point out the lady's loudness. But then the author's decision to play the music video loudly seems to cross the line. It's not just about who started it, but whether the response was proportionate. Retaliating in the same way doesn't resolve the issue and can be seen as equally rude. 

So, considering that, the author's actions were probably in the wrong because they escalated the conflict instead of de-escalating it. Even if the lady was being loud, responding by being equally loud and causing a scene is not appropriate. Therefore, the answer might be A (the author is in the wrong).
